intro: Pongamia marginata, commonly known as the Indian beech, is a deciduous tree native to Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its smooth, gray bark and alternate, pinnate leaves that are typically 10–20 cm long. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers followed by elongated pods containing flat, dark brown seeds. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in moist, well-drained soils. Pongamia marginata is also valued for its potential in biofuel production due to its high oil content.
